TEXT.English: [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Great Statesmen[COLOR_REVERT] can begin golden ages, discover new technologies, reform the government, resolve a crisis, perform a diplomatic mission, explore rival territory, settle in a city as a [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Great Statesman[COLOR_REVERT] specialist and can construct the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Administrative Center[COLOR_REVERT] building.

TEXT.English: Hoplite

[COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Gunships[COLOR_REVERT] are able to enter [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Jungle[COLOR_REVERT], [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Rainforest[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Marsh[COLOR_REVERT], cannot capture enemy cities or units, don't receive defensive bonuses, ignore terrain movement costs, can withdraw from combat, have a combat bonus against [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Armored Units[COLOR_REVERT], have a flank attack against [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Siege Weapons[COLOR_REVERT] and begin with the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Amphibious[COLOR_REVERT] promotion.

TEXT.English: The [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Conquistador[COLOR_REVERT], the Spanish replacement for the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Cuirassier[COLOR_REVERT], requires the [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Exploration[COLOR_REVERT] technology, doesn't require the [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Combined Arms[COLOR_REVERT] technology, receives a defensive bonus, is able to enter [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Jungle[COLOR_REVERT], [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Rainforest[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Marsh[COLOR_REVERT], has an attack bonus against [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Melee Units[COLOR_REVERT] except for the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Pikeman[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Militia[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Drones[COLOR_REVERT] are invisible to all units, can explore rival territory, can destroy improvements, bomb city defenses, perform recon missions, damage enemy units and have an increased chance to evade interception.

TEXT.English: [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Satellites[COLOR_REVERT] can see other [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Satellite[COLOR_REVERT] units, settle in a city as a [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Research Satellite[COLOR_REVERT], [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Commercial Satellite[COLOR_REVERT] or [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Military Satellite[COLOR_REVERT] specialist, can explore rival territory, are invisible to all units except [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Satellite[COLOR_REVERT] units and begin with the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Sentry[COLOR_REVERT] promotion.

TEXT.English: [TAB] In sailing, a brigantine is a vessel with two masts, only the forward of which is square rigged. Originally the brigantine was a small ship carrying both oars and sails. It was a favorite of Mediterranean pirates and its name comes from the Italian word brigantino, meaning brigand, and applied by extension to his ship. By the 17th century the term meant a two-masted ship. In the late 17th century, the Royal Navy used the term brigantine to refer to small two-masted vessels designed to be rowed as well as sailed, rigged with square rigs on the foremast and fore-and-aft rigging on the mainmast. By the first half of the 18th century the word had evolved to refer not to a ship type name, but rather to a particular type of rigging: square rigged on the foremast and fore-and-aft rigged on the mainmast. The word "brig" is an 18th century shortening of the word brigantine, which came to mean a vessel square-rigged on both masts. The early Oxford English Dictionary (with citations from 1720 to 1854) still defined brig as being either identical to a brigantine, or alternatively, a vessel of similar sail plan to a modern brig.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Un brigantin dsigne un petit navire deux mats gr comme un brick, et qui n'a qu'un pont, ou un petit vaisseau plat, lger et ouvert, se dplaant la voile et la rame, et qui sert combattre ou donner la chasse. Ces derniers taient rgulirement employs lors de mission d'exploration, sur mer pour la reconnaissance des ctes ou sur fleuve.
TEXT.German: [TAB] Eine Brigantine ist ein Segelschiff mit zwei Masten, deren vorderer mit Fockmast, der hintere mit Gromast bezeichnet werden. Am Fockmast fhrt eine Brigantine Rahsegel; am Gromast fhrt sie teilweise oder ausschlielich Schratsegel. Die Brigantine stellt daher eine Mischform aus Brigg und Schoner dar. Sie kann durch ihre Rahsegel Wind von hinten (raumen Wind) besser ausnutzen als ein Schoner; auerdem kann sie durch ihre Schratsegel hher am Wind segeln als eine Brigg, das heit, sie kann besser "schrg gegen den Wind" segeln. Ende des 17. Jahrhunderts wurde die Bezeichnung in Nordwesteuropa auf zweimastige, rahgetakelte Segelschiffe bertragen. Seit dem 19. Jahrhundert entstand die heutige Bedeutung des Wortes Brigantine. Je nach Takelung werden verschiedene Segelschiffstypen unterschieden, die heute zusammenfassend als Brigantine bezeichnet werden. Der meist einfach als Brigantine bezeichnete Typ fhrt am Gromast ein Gaffelsegel und darber weitere Rahsegel.

TEXT.English: Continental:Continental
TEXT.French: continentale:continentales
TEXT.German: Kontinental:Kontinental
TEXT.Italian: Continental:Continental
TEXT.Spanish: Continental:Continental

TEXT.English: Continental Soldiers are hardened warriors, educated on the field of battle in the ways of war. They received the best training and equipment available. And by the 17th century, there was more than enough "education" going on in Europe to train the budding soldier. Dozens of conflicts, including the Thirty Years' War and the Eighty Years' War, ravaged Europe in this century, making the availability of fresh training for green soldiers an easily-accessed commodity.
TEXT.French: Les gardistes sont des guerriers endurcis dont l'ducation martiale s'est faite sur le champ de bataille. Et au 17me sicle, les champs de bataille ne manquent pas pour "duquer" les soldats dbutants. Des dizaines de conflits, dont la Guerre de trente ans et la Guerre de quatre-vingts ans ravagent l'Europe au cours de ce sicle, fournissant matire entranement aux soldats inexpriments.
TEXT.German: Die Soldaten der Kontinentalgarde sind abgehrtete Krieger, die auf dem Schlachtfeld in der Kunst des Krieges unterwiesen wurden. Und im 17. Jahrhundert gab es in Europa mehr als genug "Unterrichtsmglichkeiten" fr Soldaten. Dutzende von Konflikten, unter anderem der Dreiigjhrige Krieg oder der Achtzigjhrige Krieg, wteten in Europa whrend dieses Jahrhunderts, so dass es fr unerfahrene Soldaten gengend Anfngertrainingsmglichkeiten gab.
TEXT.Italian: I soldati guardisti sono guerrieri incalliti, educati sui campi di battaglia. Ed entro il XVII secolo, in Europa c'erano abbastanza "scuole" per educare qualsiasi giovane soldato. Decine di conflitti, tra cui la Guerra dei Trent'anni e la Guerra degli 80 anni, devastarono l'Europa in questo secolo, semplificando l'addestramento dei militari in erba.
TEXT.Spanish: Los Soldados guardia son guerreros curtidos, educados en el arte de la guerra en los campos de batalla. Y, durante el s. XVII, haba "educacin" ms que suficiente en Europa para entrenar al soldado en ciernes. Decenas de conflictos, incluyendo la Guerra de los Treinta Aos y la de los Ochenta Aos, asolaron Europa durante ese siglo, haciendo que el entrenamiento de los soldados novatos fuera un bien de fcil acceso.

TEXT.English: During the Age of Sail, corvettes were one of many types of smaller warships. The role of the corvette consisted mostly of coastal patrol, fighting minor wars, supporting large fleets, or participating in show-the-flag missions. The English Navy began using small ships in the 1650s, but described them as sloops-of-war rather than corvettes. The first reference to a corvette was with the French Navy in the 1670s, which may be where the term originated. The Royal Navy did not use the term until after the Napoleonic Wars to describe a small unrated vessel somewhat larger than a sloop and smaller than a frigate.
TEXT.French: La corvette est une catgorie de petit navire de guerre, lger et rapide, qui apparat en France la fin du XVIIe sicle. C'est d'abord un petit trois mts, qui n'est jamais arm de plus de vingt canons en batterie, qui sert effectuer des missions de dcouverte. Il sert aussi de liaison pour transmettre des ordres ou des courriers. De nombreuses corvettes serviront par la suite au transport marchand. Sa taille au fil des sicles augmente au point que les corvettes de l're rvolutionnaire valent les Frgates lgres, de 6 et de 8, du sicle prcdent.
TEXT.German: Whrend des Zeitalters der Selgelschiffe waren Corvette kleinere bis mittlere Kriegsschiffe. Die Aufgabe der Corvette bestand blicherweise aus Kstenpatroulien und Unterstzung grsserer Flotten. Die Englische Navy begann die Nutzung solcher Schiffe in den 1650ern, nannte sie aber zu beginn eher Sloop-Of-War, als Corvette. Die erste namentliche Reference einer Corvette findet sich in der Franzsichen Marine um 1670 und gilt als der Ursprung dieser Bezeichnugn. Die Bezeichnung Corvette diente ab diesem Zeitpunkt zur Beschreibung eines Schiffes, welches kleiner als eine Frigatte, aber grsser als eine Sloop war.
TEXT.Italian: During the Age of Sail, corvettes were one of many types of smaller warships. The role of the corvette consisted mostly of coastal patrol, fighting minor wars, supporting large fleets, or participating in show-the-flag missions. The English Navy began using small ships in the 1650s, but described them as sloops-of-war rather than corvettes. The first reference to a corvette was with the French Navy in the 1670s, which may be where the term originated. The Royal Navy did not use the term until after the Napoleonic Wars to describe a small unrated vessel somewhat larger than a sloop and smaller than a frigate.
TEXT.Spanish: During the Age of Sail, corvettes were one of many types of smaller warships. TEXT.English: Line Infantry:Line Infantry
TXT_KEY_UNIT_VETERAN_PEDIA

Among the earliest inventions that made use of gunpowder, Cannons remained among the most important until the 19th century. By the late 1500s, cannon had become light but powerful weapons that could be easily moved and adjusted to take aim at whatever target the battle might present. Such cannons proved extremely useful against native foes, who had never experienced the devastating effects of such weapons and had no tactics to counter them.
TEXT.French: Les Canons figurent parmi les armes poudre les plus utilises jusqu'au 19me sicle. A la fin du 16me sicle, le canon s'est allg, mais est aussi devenu une arme puissante que l'on peut dplacer facilement pour cibler n'importe quel objectif. Les canons s'avrent extrmement utiles contre les ennemis indignes, qui n'ont jamais connu les effets dvastateurs de ce genre d'armes et n'ont aucune tactique pour les parer.
TEXT.German: Die Kanone war eine der ersten Erfindungen, in denen Schiepulver zum Einsatz kam. Bis ins 19. Jahrhundert hinein zhlten sie zu den wichtigsten Waffen. Gegen Ende des 16. Jahrhunderts war die Kanone zu einer leichten und mchtigen Waffe geworden, die schnell die Position wechseln konnten, um jedes Ziel ins Visier zu nehmen, das sich whrend der Schlacht bot. Solche Kanonen erwiesen sich als besonders effektiv gegen eingeborene Gegner, die noch nie mit den verheerenden Auswirkungen dieser Waffen in Berhrung gekommen waren und keine taktische Kontermglichkeit hatten.
TEXT.Italian: I cannoni furono tra le prime invenzioni a utilizzare la polvere da sparo e rimasero tra le pi importanti fino al XIX secolo. Nel tardo XVI secolo, i cannoni erano pi leggeri ma potenti che potevano essere facilmente spostate e regolate per prendere di mira i bersagli offerti durante la battaglia. Tali cannoni si dimostrarono estremamente utili contro gli avversari nativi, che non avevano mai provato i devastanti effetti di questo tipo di armi e non avevano tattiche per contrastarle.
TEXT.Spanish: Entre los primeros inventos que hicieron uso de la plvora, los Caones siguieron siendo los ms importantes hasta el s. XIX. A finales del s. XVI, los Caones se haban convertido en armas ligeras pero potentes que podan moverse fcilmente para apuntar a cualquier objetivo en la batalla. Estos Caones demostraron ser extremadamente tiles contra los indgenas enemigos, que nunca haban experimentado los efectos devastadores de tales armas y carecan de tcticas para contrarrestarlas.

TEXT.English: Hessian:Hessians
TEXT.French: Hessien:Hessiens
TEXT.German: Hessischer Sldner:Hessische Sldner
TEXT.Italian: Hessian:Hessians
TEXT.Spanish: Hessian:Hessians

TEXT.English: During the American Revolutionary War, Landgrave Frederick II of Hesse-Kassel (a principality in northern Hesse or Hessia) and other German leaders hired out thousands of conscripted subjects as auxiliaries to Great Britain to fight against the American revolutionaries. The troops were not mercenaries in the modern sense of military professionals who voluntarily hire out their own services for money. As in most armies of the eighteenth century, the men were mainly conscripts, debtors, or the victims of impressment; some were also petty criminals. Pay was low; some soldiers received nothing but their daily food. The officer corps usually consisted of career officers who had served in earlier European wars. The revenues paid for the men's service went back to the German royalty. Nevertheless, some Hessian units were respected for their discipline and excellent military skills.
TEXT.French: Pendant la guerre d'indpendance Amricaine, le Landgrave Frdric II de Hesse-Cassel (une principaut dans le Nord de la Hesse) et d'autres dirigeants allemands ont recruts des milliers de conscrits en tant qu'auxiliaire de la Grande Bretagne pour combattre les indpendantistes. Les troupes n'taient pas des mercenaires dans le sense moderne de militaires professionnels qui vendraient leur service au plus offrant. Comme dans la plupart des armes du XVIIIe sicle, ces hommes taient surtout des conscrits, des personnes endettes ou des enrols de force. Quelques uns taient galement des petits criminels. Le salaire tait faible. Quelques soldats ne recevaient mme rien d'autre que leur nourriture quotidienne. Les officiers de ces corps taient gnralement des militaires de carrire qui avaient dj services dans des guerres europennes. Les revenus obtenus pour leur recours revenaient aux monarchies allemandes. Nanmoins, les units d'Hessiens taient respects pour leur discipline et leurs excellentes aptitudes militaires.
TEXT.German: Whrend des Amerikanischen Unabhngigkeitskrieges kmpften deutsche Sldner aus Hessen auf Seiten der Englnder. Ihr Landesherr, der Landgraf von Hessen-Kassel, besserte dadurch seine Staatskasse auf. Hessen-Kassel mit seiner langen Sldnertradition verfgte ber eine groe Zahl an gut ausgebildeten Truppen und konnte deshalb groe Kontingente in Marsch setzen. In vielen hessischen Familien war es wie in der Schweiz Tradition, da immer einige Shne ihr Glck bei den Soldaten versuchten, so da kein Mangel an Freiwilligen herrschte. Die Sldner erwarben sich in Amerika schnell den Ruf, besonders tchtige und gefhrliche Gegner zu sein. Die amerikanischen Milizen wurden von der disziplinierten europischen Infanterie frmlich berrannt. Der Feuergeschwindigkeit und vor allem dem gefrchteten Bajonettangriff der Hessen hatten sie nichts entgegenzusetzen. Ein hessischer Oberst schrieb: "Die Riflemans sind mehrentheils mit dem Bajonett an die Bume gespiet worden; diese Leute verdienen eher Mitleid als Furcht. Sie mssen immer eine Viertelstunde Zeit haben, um ein Gewehr zu laden und in dieser Zeit fhlen sie unsere Kugeln und Bajonette". (Quelle: www.kriegsreisende.de)
TEXT.Italian: During the American Revolutionary War, Landgrave Frederick II of Hesse-Kassel (a principality in northern Hesse or Hessia) and other German leaders hired out thousands of conscripted subjects as auxiliaries to Great Britain to fight against the American revolutionaries. The troops were not mercenaries in the modern sense of military professionals who voluntarily hire out their own services for money. As in most armies of the eighteenth century, the men were mainly conscripts, debtors, or the victims of impressment; some were also petty criminals. Pay was low; some soldiers received nothing but their daily food. The officer corps usually consisted of career officers who had served in earlier European wars. The revenues paid for the men's service went back to the German royalty. Nevertheless, some Hessian units were respected for their discipline and excellent military skills.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]During the American Revolutionary War, Landgrave Frederick II of Hesse-Kassel (a principality in northern Hesse or Hessia) and other German leaders hired out thousands of conscripted subjects as auxiliaries to Great Britain to fight against the American revolutionaries. As in most armies of the eighteenth century, the men were mainly conscripts, debtors, or the victims of impressment; some were also petty criminals. Pay was low; some soldiers received nothing but their daily food. The officer corps usually consisted of career officers who had served in earlier European wars. The revenues paid for the men's service went back to the German royalty. Nevertheless, some Hessian units were respected for their discipline and excellent military skills.

TEXT.English: Light Artillery:Light Artillery
TEXT.French: Artillerie lgre:Artilleries lgres
TEXT.German: Leichte Artillerie:Leichte Artillerien

TEXT.English: While a time of great advancement in philosophy, science and art, the Renaissance also marked the beginning of a period of rapid development in artillery. Prior to the Renaissance, cannons were essentially thickened pots into which gunpowder and a heavy object were dropped and then fired and - if lucky - hit a target in the general direction the cannon was aimed. (If unlucky, the cannon simply exploded.)[PARAGRAPH:1]Developments from tactical innovators like King Gustavus Adolphus of Sweden turned artillery from uncertain weapons of war into dangerous, highly-trained instruments of destruction deployed on all the major battlefields of Europe. Artillery units in the 18th century were often the elite of any European army, as artillerymen needed a significant amount of knowledge to successfully perform their duties, including training in geometry, chemistry, and physics. At the command of these elite soldiers were a plethora of machines of destruction, ranging from light "swivel" guns that could be fired by a single artilleryman to guns that could fire enormous projectiles over miles, all capable of dealing crushing damage to an enemy.
TEXT.French: En plus d'tre une priode d'volution spectaculaire dans les domaines de la philosophie, la science et l'art, la Renaissance a galement marqu le dbut d'une priode de dveloppement rapide de l'artillerie. Avant la Renaissance, les canons avaient surtout l'apparence de pots pais dans lesquels on jetait de la poudre et un objet lourd avant de faire feu, et si le ciel tait avec lui, le tireur atteignait une cible qui se trouvait vaguement dans la direction vise. (Pour les moins chanceux et les superstitieux du vendredi 13, le canon explosait.)[PARAGRAPH:1]Un certain nombre d'innovations tactiques, apportes entre autres par le roi Gustave Adolphe de Sude, ont radicalement mtamorphos l'artillerie : d'une arme de guerre incertaine, cette unit s'est transforme pour devenir dangereuse, bien entrane, et un vritable instrument de destruction dploy sur les principaux champs de bataille europens. Au 18me sicle, les units d'artillerie taient souvent considres comme l'lite de toute arme europenne tant les artilleurs devaient avoir une connaissance pousse (notamment en gomtrie, en chimie et en physique) pour remplir correctement leur devoir. Ces soldats d'lite taient aux commandes d'une kyrielle de machines de destruction, allant du canon lger mont sur un pied pivotant pouvant tre manipul par un seul artilleur des canons capables d'envoyer des projectiles des kilomtres, tous capables d'infliger de gros dgts l'ennemi.
TEXT.German: Die Renaissance war nicht nur eine Zeit groer Fortschritte in Philosophie, Wissenschaft und Kunst; in diese Periode fllt auch der Beginn einer rapiden Entwicklung der Artillerie. Vor der Renaissance waren Kanonen im Prinzip nur dicke Tpfe, die mit Schiepulver und einem schweren Gegenstand gefllt und dann abgefeuert wurden; mit etwas Glck traf man damit ein Ziel ungefhr in der Richtung, in welche die Kanone zeigte. (Wenn man Pech hatte, flog einem die Kanone selbst um die Ohren.)[PARAGRAPH:1]Die Entwicklungen taktischer Innovatoren wie Knig Gustav Adolf von Schweden machten aus den unsicheren Artilleriegeschtzen gefhrliche, przise Vernichtungswaffen, die auf allen groen Schlachtfeldern Europas zum Einsatz kamen. Im 18. Jahrhundert zhlten die Artillerie-Einheiten oft zur Elite der europischen Armeen, da Artilleristen zur Erfllung ihrer Aufgaben ein solides Grundwissen brauchten und unter anderem in Geometrie, Chemie und Physik ausgebildet wurden. Diese Elitesoldaten waren Herr ber alle mglichen Vernichtungswaffen, von leichten "Drehbassen", die ein einzelner Artillerist abfeuern konnte, bis hin zu Kanonen, deren enorme Geschosse meilenweit fliegen und dem Feind vernichtenden Schaden zufgen konnten.
TEXT.Italian: Pur essendo stato un periodo di grandi innovazioni nel campo della filosofia, della scienza e dell'arte, il Rinascimento segn anche l'inizio di un rapido sviluppo dell'artiglieria. Prima del Rinascimento i cannoni erano essenzialmente robusti "pentoloni" in cui erano messi un oggetto pesante e polvere da sparo, a cui veniva poi dato fuoco: se si era fortunati il proiettile colpiva un bersaglio nella direzione generale in cui era puntato il cannone (se si era sfortunati il cannone semplicemente esplodeva).[PARAGRAPH:1]Gli sviluppi di innovatori tattici come re Gustavo Adolfo di Svezia trasformarono l'artiglieria da complesso di armi dall'esito bellico incerto in reparti pericolosi e altamente addestrati, schierati su tutti i maggiori campi di battaglia europei. Le unit d'artiglieria del XVIII secolo erano spesso l'elite di qualsiasi esercito europeo, dato che un artigliere aveva bisogno di una importante quantit di conoscenze per poter svolgere il proprio compito: queste comprendono fondamenti di geometria, chimica e fisica. Sotto il comando di questi soldati d'elite c'erano una pletora di macchine votate alla distruzione, che andavano dalle pi leggere, posizionate su piattaforme girevoli, utilizzate anche da un singolo artigliere, a cannoni che potevano sparare enormi proiettili a distanza di miglia, in grado di infliggere al nemico danni ingenti.
TEXT.Spanish: Aunque el Renacimiento fue una poca de grandes avances en filosofa, ciencia y arte, tambin marc el inicio de un periodo de rpido desarrollo de la artillera. Antes del Renacimiento, los caones eran en esencia gruesos calderos en los que se embuta plvora y objeto pesados, se disparaba y, con suerte, se daba a un blanco en la direccin aproximada hacia la que se apuntaba el arma (si no haba suerte, el can simplemente explotaba).[PARAGRAPH:1]Con los inventos de los innovadores tcticos, como el rey Gustavo Adolfo de Suecia, la artillera pas de ser un arma de guerra inestable a un conjunto de instrumentos de destruccin muy sofisticados que se desplegaron por todos los campos de batalla europeos. Las unidades de artillera del s. XVIII solan conformar la lite de cualquier ejrcito europeo, ya que los artilleros necesitaban una gran cantidad de conocimientos para conseguir llevar a cabo su cometido, incluyendo estudios de geometra, qumica y fsica. Estos soldados de lite tenan a su cargo una pltora de aparatos de destruccin, que iban desde los ligeros caones de colisa, que podan ser disparados por un solo artillero, hasta las piezas que podan disparar proyectiles enormes a kilmetros de distancia, capaces de hacer un dao aplastante.

TEXT.English: Man-o-War:Man-o-Wars

The Man-o-War was the most powerful ship of its era. First created under the reign of the English king Henry VIII in the 16th century, these massive weapons of war quickly became the most feared vessels in the seas. The Great Harry and the Mary Rose were two of the first Man-o-War's, each capable of carrying over four hundred crewmen and over one hundred cannon. Strangely enough, both the Great Harry and the Mary Rose met rather inglorious ends - the Great Harry is thought to have burnt while docked and the Mary Rose was sunk by an inferior French vessel.
TEXT.French: Les Vaisseaux de guerre sont les navires les plus puissants de leur poque. Cr pour la premire fois sous le rgne du roi anglais Henry VIII, au 16me sicle, ces armes de guerre massives deviennent bientt les navires les plus redouts des mers. Le Henri Grce Dieu et la Mary Rose, deux des premiers Vaisseaux de guerre, sont capables de transporter chacun plus de quatre cents hommes et plus de cent canons. Chose trange, ils ont tous deux connu une fin peu glorieuse : le Henri Grce Dieu aurait brl quai et la Mary Rose a t coule par un bateau franais de moindre puissance.
TEXT.German: Die Kniglichen Linienschiffe der Heimatflotte waren den leichteren Linienschiffen der Kolonien und ihren anderen Schiffen berlegen, weil sie mindestens ein Kampfdeck mehr besaen und entsprechend mehr Schiffskanonen und Feuerkraft.
TEXT.Italian: Le navi da guerra (Man-o-War, in inglese) erano i pi potenti vascelli della propria era. Furono costruiti per la prima volta sotto il regno di Re Enrico VIII d'Inghilterra nel XVI secolo e divennero ben presto le navi pi temute in tutti i mari. Due fra le prime navi da guerra furono la Great Harry e la Mary Rose, ognuna in grado di trasportare oltre 400 uomini di equipaggio e pi di 100 cannoni. Stranamente, sia la Great Harry che la Mary Rose subirono sorti piuttosto ingloriose: pare che la Great Harry sia bruciata mentre era attraccata, mentre la Mary Rose stata affondata da un inferiore vascello francese.
TEXT.Spanish: El Buque de guerra ("Man-o-War") fue el barco ms poderoso de su poca. Creados en un principio durante el reinado del monarca ingls Enrique VIII en el s. XVI, estas enormes armas de guerra se convirtieron rpidamente en los veleros ms temidos de los mares. El "Great Harry" y el "Mary Rose" fueron dos de los primeros Buques de guerra, y cada uno era capaz de llevar cerca de cuatrocientos tripulantes y cien caones. Aunque, extraamente, ambos tuvieron un final bastante indigno: se cree que la "Great Harry" se quem mientras estaba atracada y la "Mary Rose" fue hundida por un velero francs de menor calado.

TEXT.English: A mortar is an indirect fire weapon that fires explosive projectiles known as (mortar) bombs at low velocities, short ranges, and high-arcing ballistic trajectories. It is typically muzzle-loading (i.e., loading from the forward, open end of the gun's barrel) and has a barrel length less than 15 times its caliber. Mortars have existed for hundreds of years, first seeing use in siege warfare. From the 18th to the early 20th century very heavy, relatively immobile siege mortars were used, of up to one metre calibre, often made of cast iron and with outside barrel diameter many times that of the bore diameter. In the French and Indian War (1754 - 1762) especially the French troops used 15 inch mortars while sieging British fortifications.
TEXT.French: Un mortier ou lance-mine est une bouche feu tirant inclinaison leve (plus de 45), pour effectuer des tirs indirects. La trajectoire courbe, en forme de cloche, du projectile permet d'atteindre un objectif plac derrire un obstacle, qu'un canon ne permet pas d'engager car la trajectoire de son projectile est tendue. L'nergie produite par le recul est directement absorbe par le sol ou la plate-forme renforce d'un vhicule. L'arme a un tube court et gnralement lisse, sans rayures.
TEXT.German: Ein Mrser ist ein Steilfeuergeschtz mit kurzem Rohr, mit dem auf kurze Distanz Explosivgeschosse verschossen werden. Mrser sind typischerweise Vorderlader, deren Rohr im Verhltnis zu ihrem Kaliber deutlich krzer ist, wodurch sie ihr typisches Aussehen erhalten. Mrser existieren bereits sehr mehreren hundert Jahren. Sie waren in erster Linie Waffen des Festungs- und Stellungskrieges. Als solche hatten sie die Aufgabe eine feindliche Befestigung sturmreif zu schieen. Schwere Mrser wirkten vor allem durch Zerstren von Befestigungswerken, Deckungen und Hindernissen. Im Franzsisch-Indianischen Krieg (1754-1762) setzen vor allem die Franzosen schwere 15 Zoll Mrser zur Bekmpfung britischer Befestigungsanlagen ein.
TEXT.Italian: A mortar is an indirect fire weapon that fires explosive projectiles known as (mortar) bombs at low velocities, short ranges, and high-arcing ballistic trajectories. It is typically muzzle-loading (i.e., loading from the forward, open end of the gun's barrel) and has a barrel length less than 15 times its caliber. Mortars have existed for hundreds of years, first seeing use in siege warfare. From the 18th to the early 20th century very heavy, relatively immobile siege mortars were used, of up to one metre calibre, often made of cast iron and with outside barrel diameter many times that of the bore diameter. In the French and Indian War (1754 - 1762) especially the French troops used 15 inch mortars while sieging British fortifications.

Mortars have existed for hundreds of years, first seeing use in siege warfare. TEXT.English: [TAB] Ranger in the original meaning of the word designates a person who is specially trained to traverse rough terrain, esp. woodland, relatively quickly; and who possesses the according survival skills to live in the wilderness for a prolonged amount of time. The term "Ranger" was first used in North America in the early 17th century; however, the first ranger company was not officially commissioned until King Philip's War (1676) and then they were used in the four French and Indian Wars . Rangers also fought in the American Revolution , the War of 1812 , and the American Civil War.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Le garde forestier est gnralement un fonctionnaire charg de patrouiller (ventuellement cheval) dans la fort et d'autres endroits dans la nature. Il peut aussi dans certains pays s'agir de gardes privs. En Amrique du Nord, les gardes-forestiers constituent une rserve militaire qui peut servir en combat en tant de guerre. Ils furent ainsi utiliser partir de la guerre du Roi Philippe (1676), puis dans tous les conflits successifs jusqu' la guerre de Scession.
TEXT.German: [TAB] Die Rangers berufen sich auf die Tradition der ersten Siedler in den USA, die unter Ausnutzung des Gelndes gegen Indianer und britische oder franzsische Truppen kmpften. Namenspatron sind Rogers' Rangers, die unter Robert Rogers auf britischer Seite im Franzosen- und Indianerkrieg kmpften. Dessen zusammengestellter Ausbildungsplan aus Berichten der Rogers Ranger sind u.a. bis heute noch Grundlage des Kleinen Krieges. Auch im amerikanischen Brgerkrieg waren Ranger-Einheiten, vor allem auf konfderierter Seite als Bushwhacker, hinter den feindlichen Linien eingesetzt.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB] Ranger in the original meaning of the word designates a person who is specially trained to traverse rough terrain, esp. woodland, relatively quickly; and who possesses the according survival skills to live in the wilderness for a prolonged amount of time. The term "Ranger" was first used in North America in the early 17th century; however, the first ranger company was not officially commissioned until King Philip's War (1676) and then they were used in the four French and Indian Wars . Rangers also fought in the American Revolution , the War of 1812 , and the American Civil War.

The term "Ranger" was first used in North America in the early 17th century; however, the first ranger company was not officially commissioned until King Philip's War (1676) and then they were used in the four French and Indian Wars . Rangers also fought in the American Revolution , the War of 1812 , and the American Civil War.

TEXT.English: Seasoned Scout:Seasoned Scouts

The eyes and ears of any colony, Scouts seek out valuable resources and information for those back home. Lone riders capable of crossing vast tracks of territory faster than any other, these isolated adventurers journey across the land, watching enemy troops, exploring native villages, or stumbling upon lost caches of treasure. A colony can survive without Scouts on its side, but only the same sort of existence a man can live without eyes or ears - challenging.
TEXT.French: Les Eclaireurs sont les yeux et les oreilles de la colonie et sont constamment la recherche de ressources ou d'information prcieuses pour leurs compatriotes. Cavaliers solitaires, capables de traverser de vastes contres bien plus vite que n'importe quel colon, ces aventuriers voyagent travers tout le pays, surveillant les troupes ennemies, explorant les villages indignes ou dcouvrant des trsors cachs. Une colonie peut survivre sans Eclaireur en son sein, mais la manire d'un homme dpourvu de yeux et d'oreilles, c'est--dire difficilement.
TEXT.German: Spher, die Augen und Ohren einer Kolonie, suchen nach wertvollen Ressourcen und Informationen fr Kolonisten. Diese isoliert lebenden Abenteurer, die als einsame Reiter in der Lage sind, weite Territorien schneller zu durchqueren als alle anderen, ziehen durchs Land, beobachten feindliche Truppen, erforschen die Eingeborenen und stolpern auch durchaus manchmal ber versteckte Schtze. Eine Kolonie kann auch ohne Spher berleben, jedoch wre es so wie ein Leben ohne Ohren und Augen: ziemlich schwierig.
TEXT.Italian: Gli scout sono gli occhi e le orecchie della colonia, sempre alla ricerca di preziose risorse e informazioni per i propri compagni a casa. Sono cavalieri solitari, in grado di attraversare vaste distese di territorio pi rapidamente di chiunque altro; questi avventurieri viaggiano attraverso la terra, osservando le truppe nemiche, esplorando i villaggi dei nativi, o scoprendo perdute riserve di tesori. Una colonia pu sopravvivere senza scout, ma sar un'esistenza come quella di un uomo senza occhi oppure orecchie: difficile.
TEXT.Spanish: Los Batidores son los ojos y los odos de cualquier colonia y buscan informacin y recursos valiosos para los que se han quedado en casa. Son jinetes solitarios, capaces de salvar grandes extensiones de terreno con ms rapidez que nadie y se adentran en tierra para vigilar a las tropas enemigas, explorar las aldeas indgenas o encontrar tesoros perdidos. Una colonia puede sobrevivir sin contar con Batidores, pero con la misma clase de existencia que llevara un hombre sin ojos ni odos: difcil.

TEXT.English: In the British colony of Massachusetts Bay, all able-bodied men between the ages of 16 and 60 were required to participate in their local militia. As early as 1645 in the Massachusetts Bay Colony, some men were selected from the general ranks of town-based "training bands" to be ready for rapid deployment. Men so selected were designated as minutemen. They were usually drawn from settlers of each town, and so it was very common for them to be fighting alongside relatives and friends.
TEXT.French: Dans les colonies de la Nouvelle-Angleterre, le concept de milice apparat assez tt et assure la survie de la jeune colonie lors de conflits contre les Amrindiens. La premire milice s'tablit en Virginie, en 1632, et repose sur un recrutement local et de courtes priodes de service actif lors d'urgences. Tout homme capable de porter une arme doit l'apporter l'glise et s'exercer aprs le service religieux. Ds 1645, au sein de la colonie de la baie du Massachusetts, quelques hommes furent slectionns parmi les troupes locales pour tre prts un dploiement rapide. Les minutemen dont le nom deviendra clbre un sicle plus tard taient gnralement choisis parmi les colons d'une mme ville, ainsi il n'tait pas rare pour eux de combattre aux cts de cousins ou de beaux-frres.
TEXT.German: Schon zu Zeiten der Massachusetts Bay Colony 1645 wurden einige Mnner aus dem Aufgebot der verschiedenen rtlichen Milizen fr schnellen Einsatz ausgewhlt. Die Miliz der Provinz Massachusetts war bereits in vielen Konflikten im Kampf eingesetzt worden, so in Knig Philipps Krieg, im Franzosen- und Indianerkrieg und schlielich in der Schlacht von Lexington und Concord. Jede Generation der Siedler in Neuengland war mit dem Kmpfen vertraut, jeder Ort besa eine Miliz, und jeder wehrfhige Mann zwischen 16 und 60 war verpflichtet, seinen Dienst in der Miliz zu leisten. Allerdings gab es hier viele Ausnahmeregelungen, zum Beispiel fr bestimmte Berufsgruppen. Der Dienst in der Miliz wurde in sogenannten Militia Acts und nach dem Ausbruch des Unabhngigkeitskrieges in Militia Bills geregelt. Viele dieser Mnner waren Landwirte. Viele waren untereinander verwandt, und so war es blich, neben seinen Cousins und Schwgern zu kmpfen.
TEXT.Italian: In the British colony of Massachusetts Bay, all able-bodied men between the ages of 16 and 60 were required to participate in their local militia. As early as 1645 in the Massachusetts Bay Colony, some men were selected from the general ranks of town-based "training bands" to be ready for rapid deployment. Men so selected were designated as minutemen. They were usually drawn from settlers of each town, and so it was very common for them to be fighting alongside relatives and friends.
TEXT.Spanish: In the British colony of Massachusetts Bay, all able-bodied men between the ages of 16 and 60 were required to participate in their local militia. As early as 1645 in the Massachusetts Bay Colony, some men were selected from the general ranks of town-based "training bands" to be ready for rapid deployment. Men so selected were designated as minutemen. They were usually drawn from settlers of each town, and so it was very common for them to be fighting alongside relatives and friends.

TEXT.English: [TAB] In the 18th and the earlier part of the 19th centuries, a sloop-of-war was a small sailing warship (also known as one of the escort types) with a single gun deck that carried anything up to eighteen cannons. As the rating system covered all vessels with 20 guns and above, this meant that the term sloop-of-war actually encompassed all the unrated combat vessels including the very small gun-brigs and cutters. In technical terms, even the more specialised bomb vessels and fireships were classed as sloops-of-war, and in practice these were actually employed in the sloop role when not carrying out their specialised functions. A ship sloop was generally the equivalent of the smaller corvette of the French Navy (although the French term also covered ships up up to 24 guns, which were classed as 'post ships' within the Sixth Rate of the British Navy). The name corvette was subsequently also applied to British vessels, but not until the 1830s. A sloop-of-war was smaller than a sailing frigate and outside the rating system. In general, a sloop-of-war would be under the command of a master and commander rather than a post captain, although in day-to-day use at sea the commanding officer of any naval vessels would be addressed as "captain". Until 1794 the master and commander strictly speaking held the permenent rank of lieutenant, and reverted to that rank when he gave up command of the sloop-of-war; in 1794 the rank of commander was created.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Au temps de la marine voile, le sloop (de la mme origine tymologique que le franais chaloupe), ou plus exactement le sloop-of-war, dsignait en Angleterre, les navires plus petits que les frgates, arms de dix dix-huit canons sur un seul pont. Les Anglais distinguaient deux variantes principales de sloop : le ship sloop qui, avec ses trois mts, quivalait peu prs la corvette franaise ; le brig sloop avec deux mts, est appel brick en France. Au dbut du XXe sicle, le terme sloop dsignait un navire d'escorte anti sous-marin, arm de canon de 102 mm et de grenades sous-marines. Lors de la Seconde Guerre mondiale, il a cd la place aux corvettes, puis aux frgates.
TEXT.German: [TAB] Die Kriegsschiffbezeichnung Sloop hat ihren Ursprung in dem gleichnamigen einmastigen Schiffstyp. Sie bildeten im 17. Jahrhundert die kleinsten bewaffneten Marineeinheiten fr Untersttzungsaufgaben wie Nachrichtenbermittlung und Aufklrung und waren im Gegensatz zu grsseren Schiffen nicht klassifiziert. Diese Fahrzeuge hatten zunchst einen Leutnant als Kommandanten, jedoch ohne weiteren Offizier, vor allem aber keinen Navigator/Segelmeister (engl. Sailing-Master oder kurz Master). Weil Untersttzungsfahrzeuge in der Seekriegsfhrung im Verlaufe des 17. Jahrhundert immer bedeutender wurden und vor allem auch abseits der Ksten operierten, wurde auch ein Navigator notwendig. Daraus entstand der Rang des Master and Commander, ein kommandierender Seeoffizier, der zugleich Navigator war.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB] In the 18th and the earlier part of the 19th centuries, a sloop-of-war was a small sailing warship (also known as one of the escort types) with a single gun deck that carried anything up to eighteen cannons. As the rating system covered all vessels with 20 guns and above, this meant that the term sloop-of-war actually encompassed all the unrated combat vessels including the very small gun-brigs and cutters. In technical terms, even the more specialised bomb vessels and fireships were classed as sloops-of-war, and in practice these were actually employed in the sloop role when not carrying out their specialised functions. A ship sloop was generally the equivalent of the smaller corvette of the French Navy (although the French term also covered ships up up to 24 guns, which were classed as 'post ships' within the Sixth Rate of the British Navy). The name corvette was subsequently also applied to British vessels, but not until the 1830s. A sloop-of-war was smaller than a sailing frigate and outside the rating system. In general, a sloop-of-war would be under the command of a master and commander rather than a post captain, although in day-to-day use at sea the commanding officer of any naval vessels would be addressed as "captain". Until 1794 the master and commander strictly speaking held the permenent rank of lieutenant, and reverted to that rank when he gave up command of the sloop-of-war; in 1794 the rank of commander was created.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB] In the 18th and the earlier part of the 19th centuries, a sloop-of-war was a small sailing warship (also known as one of the escort types) with a single gun deck that carried anything up to eighteen cannons. As the rating system covered all vessels with 20 guns and above, this meant that the term sloop-of-war actually encompassed all the unrated combat vessels including the very small gun-brigs and cutters. In technical terms, even the more specialised bomb vessels and fireships were classed as sloops-of-war, and in practice these were actually employed in the sloop role when not carrying out their specialised functions. A ship sloop was generally the equivalent of the smaller corvette of the French Navy (although the French term also covered ships up up to 24 guns, which were classed as 'post ships' within the Sixth Rate of the British Navy). The name corvette was subsequently also applied to British vessels, but not until the 1830s. A sloop-of-war was smaller than a sailing frigate and outside the rating system. In general, a sloop-of-war would be under the command of a master and commander rather than a post captain, although in day-to-day use at sea the commanding officer of any naval vessels would be addressed as "captain". Until 1794 the master and commander strictly speaking held the permenent rank of lieutenant, and reverted to that rank when he gave up command of the sloop-of-war; in 1794 the rank of commander was created.
